intro: Cinchona decurrentifolia, commonly known as the Andean quinine tree, is a species native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–15 meters and has a dense, rounded crown. Its leaves are elliptical,革质 (leathery), and have a distinctive reddish hue when young. The tree is notable for its historical significance in the production of quinine, a compound used in the treatment of malaria.
